conclusion: To determine the power of the external force doing work, follow these steps.
Calculate the induced emf in the conductor rod OC.
The conductor rod OC is rotating in a uniform magnetic field B. The length of the conductor rod OC is r.
The induced emf (ğ“”) in a conductor rotating in a magnetic field is given by: ğ“” = B â‹… v â‹… r.
Since OC rotates uniformly with an angular velocity Ï‰, the tangential velocity v at point C is: v = Ï‰ â‹… r.
Substitute the tangential velocity into the emf formula.
Substituting v = Ï‰ â‹… r into the emf formula: ğ“” = B â‹… (Ï‰ â‹… r) â‹… r = B â‹… Ï‰ â‹… rÂ².
Calculate the current I through the resistor R.
The current I through the resistor R is given by Ohm's law: I = ğ“”/R. Substituting the value of ğ“”: I = (B â‹… Ï‰ â‹… rÂ²)/R.
Determine the power P dissipated in the resistor R.
The power P dissipated in the resistor R is given by: P = IÂ² â‹… R. Substituting the value of I: P = ((B â‹… Ï‰ â‹… rÂ²)/R)Â² â‹… R.
Simplifying the expression: P = (BÂ² â‹… Ï‰Â² â‹… râ´)/R.
Conclusion: The power of the external force doing work is: (BÂ² Ï‰Â² râ´)/R.
